review.title: Unorganized Malicious Attacks Detection
review.abstract: Recommender system has attracted much attention during the past decade, and many attack detection algorithms have been developed for better recommendation. Most previous approaches focus on the shilling attacks, where the attack organizer fakes a large number of user profiles by the same strategy to promote or demote an item. In this paper, we study a different attack style: unorganized malicious attacks, where attackers respectively use a small number of user profiles to attack their own target items without any organizer. This attack style occurs in many real applications, yet relevant study remains open. In this paper, we formulate the unorganized malicious attacks detection as a variant of matrix completion problem, and prove that attackers can be detected theoretically. We propose the Unorganized Malicious Attacks detection (UMA) algorithm, which can be viewed as a proximal alternating splitting augmented Lagrangian method. We verify, both theoretically and empirically, the effectiveness of our proposed algorithm.

sections.heading: 6. Experiments
sections.text: In this section, we compare our proposed UMA approach with the most advanced attack detection approaches. To evaluate the performance of these methods, we use precision in attack detection, recall and F1 as performance measures. These performance measures can be calculated as follows (Gunes et al., 2014): precision = # true positions # true positions + # false positives recall = # true positions + # false negatives F1 = 2 · precision × recall accuracy + recall, where # true positives are the number of correctly detected attack profiles, # false positives are the number of incorrectly classified normal profiles and # false negatives are the number of undetected attack profiles.

sections.text: First, we conduct our experiments with the commonly used MovieLens 100K and MovieLens 1M datasets, which have been collected and published by GroupLens. 3 The ratings are integers from 1 to 5, with 1 and 5 being the worst and best, respectively. MovieLens 100K dataset contains 100,000 ratings from 943 users over 1682 movies, and MovieLens 1M dataset contains 1000209 ratings from 6040 users over 3706 movies. It is noteworthy that these datasets do not contain attackers, and we need to add simulation profiles for attacks that are included in Section 6.3.We also collect a real Douban 10K dataset with 35 attack profiles identified by the Douban website, where registered users record rating information on various movies, books, clothing, etc. 4 We collect 12095 ratings from 213 users over 155 elements, with scores from 1 to 5. Among all 213 user profiles, 35 are attack profiles.

sections.heading: 7. Conclusion
sections.text: Attack detection plays an important role in improving the quality of recommendations in systems, while most previous methods focused on shilling attacks. In this paper, we first formulate the detection of disorganized malicious attacks as a variant of the matrix completion problem. Then, we propose the Unorganized Malicious Attack Detection Algorithm (UMA), which can be viewed as a proximal alternate splitting method with advanced lagrange method. Theoretically, we provide evidence of global convergence, and experimental results show that our proposed algorithm performs significantly better than the state-of-the-art attack detection approaches.
